Introduction Current clinical management of patients with prostate cancer (PCa) relies on costly and painful multi-core needle biopsies performed for both diagnosis and active surveillance. Due to the relatively low occurrence of high-risk cancers, 80–90% PCa patients could potentially be spared unnecessary biopsies [ 1 2 3 4 5 6 2 7 2 5 8 Imaging studies that add assessment of quantitative diffusion parameter [ 8 9 10 2 11 12 13 8 9 14 2 12 13 14 15 8 10 11 12 15 16 17 14 18 19 5 8 14 2 5 6 9 14 Emerging artificial intelligence (AI) deep learning (DL) reconstruction and denoising methods hold potential to substantially accelerate bpMRI and improve image quality [ 20 21 22 23 24 23 24 23 14 Quantitative validation of the front-end AI/DL-aided reconstruction and image processing provided by scanner vendors is thus particularly challenging and requires a reference platform compatible with the clinical workflow. According to QIBA and FDA guidelines for quantitative imaging devices [ 25 26 27 We have recently developed a quantitative multiparametric phantom for objective bias assessment of relaxation and diffusion parameters in prostate tissue relevant ranges [ 28 2 2. Patient Studies The prospective, single-center study was IRB-approved and HIPAA-compliant. Informed consent was obtained from all participants. The AI/DL-accelerated protocols were added to SOC exams for six patients (enrolled June–December 2024) on active surveillance for PCa with lesion pathologic grade initially obtained by needle biopsy [ 3 Table 1 30 2 31 32 2.3. Discussion AI/DL accelerated acquisition [ 20 21 6 8 9 14 2 in vivo 2 26 33 34 10 35 Our study confirmed the benefits of AI/DL accelerated bpMRI for prostate imaging [ 20 21 32 36 2 20 21 22 32 36 Much of the current research on multi-system harmonization of bi-parametric prostate MRI has been focused on downstream lesion segmentation and classification analysis in retrospective studies [ 37 38 39 40 41 42 14 24 27 37 38 41 42 26 33 34 37 38 41 42 14 25 27 43 14 24 27 43 23 26 27 22 32 36 44 The present prospective study implements the recommended harmonization approach [ 26 27 33 34 28 23 26 2 2 2 2 10 2 2 10 31 Our study had several limitations. The tests were performed on two systems with a small number of MR-visible low-grade lesions and a two-reader assessment. This may potentially increase the variability of qualitative scores for subjective evaluation, although we observed good inter-reader agreement and consistency with quantitative phantom SNR evaluation. Larger population, multi-system, multi-reader studies with correlation to clinical outcomes (including high and low PCa grades) are needed to ascertain the added benefit of the AI/DL-accelerated q-bpMRI protocols for PCa patient management [ 14 23 36 20 21 31 36 2 Harmonization was based on the correction of additive bias for mean ROI metrics, which do not affect voxel-based image texture features and histograms used for radiomics analysis [ 40 41 42 2 2 45 46 2 1 in vivo 2 5. Conclusions The developed protocol enables harmonization of the vendor-provided AI/DL-accelerated acquisition options to establish credibility and streamline implementation of prostate q-bpMRI protocols in a multi-vendor clinical environment. AI/DL-aided reconstruction reduces acquisition time with improved SNR and resolution versus the SOC protocol. A multiparametric phantom allows assessment of biases directly for clinical scan protocols with arbitrary acquisition settings on a per-patient basis. The observed biases were due to acquisition parameters for T 2 2 Acknowledgments We acknowledge the support of clinical research coordinator, Sarah Culver, for patient scheduling and consenting to the IRB for MR technology development. We are thankful to MRI technologist, Jesus E Fajardo, and vendor representatives, Nig Jin and Ramin Jafari, for their help with the initial implementation of WIP DL/AI protocols on clinical 3T systems. Institutional Review Board Statement The Institutional Review Board approved the study (IRB protocol # HUM 00175599, approved on 20 March 2024). Informed Consent Statement Informed consent was obtained from all subjects involved in the study. Data Availability Statement Essential data is contained in the article and Supplementary Figures. Conflicts of Interest S.D.S., T.L.C., and D.M. are co-inventors of diffusion kurtosis phantom IP, assigned to and managed by the University of Michigan. metadata.Title of this paper: Temperature-dependent self-diffusion coefficients of water and six selected molecular 16 liquids for calibration in accurate 1H NMR PFG measurements
